title: freedomgo
author: freedomgo
content: This story is truly heartbreaking, knowing that a 72-year-old woman lost her entire life savings and inheritance, totaling $224,000, to crypto scammers. They used a deepfake video of Christopher Luxon, the New Zealand Prime Minister, to lure her in. She got interested and responded, which is where things took a dark turn. A scammer, pretending to be Adam Manolas, who claimed to be an expert investment adviser, convinced her to open accounts with Easy Crypto and Binance. She thought her Bitcoin was safe in her Binance wallet, but instead, it was sent to an account controlled by the scammers. Once they emptied her savings, they even took funds that were meant for her grandchildren. In one of their last calls, she overheard him say, "This woman has no money."It's painful to see how these scammers target older people, especially those who aren't tech-savvy and are more vulnerable to these tricks. I can't even begin to imagine how our granny feels after losing everything she worked for and inherited. Some might find it too much to handle and could even consider taking their own lives because of it. These scammers are truly cruel, and they deserve to rot in hell.Her message really shows the deep pain she's endured with her experience.Quote‘Evil will come to you’In an email this week, Creasy castigated the scammers who stole her life savings, warning that “evil will come to you”.“You told me you are known as ‘Money Manolas’,” she wrote. “Are you a thief?”“If you entrusted me with your money I would pay you back when you asked for it.“I hope your 74-year-old mother is safe from predators like you.”Creasy told the Herald Luxon’s apparent endorsement was “the fishhook” for her investing. She’d believed her money was “safe and secure”.It was devastating to learn she’d been tricked by criminals and that her retirement nest egg was gone.“First of all I felt angry and then I felt foolish, then I felt really ashamed.”source : https://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/news/national/pensioner-loses-224k-after-being-tricked-by-ai-deepfake-christopher-luxon-cryptocurrency-investment-scam/

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Everyone has the right to do what they want with their money, right - at least that's some kind of general attitude here on the forum? Let's imagine for a moment that this woman's bank had been a little less friendly towards investing in cryptocurrencies or had asked the client for additional verification before the money left the account, maybe this woman would have saved her money. These are not sad stories for me, but rather stories about ignorance and greed that are very skillfully used by scammers all over the world.People who gamble with everything they have don't have much of a chance in life anyway...

comments.author: mindrust
comments.body: She should have used legacy banking. Crypto is not for everyone. Maybe she was going to get scammed anyway whether it was crypto or legacy banking she was using. Still though, crypto is indeed making the scammers’ job easier nobody can deny that because the transactions are irreversible. Old people should steer clear of crypto unless they are very well informed and know exactly what they are doing. One missclick and all gone. It is that easy to lose money in crypto. It is all fun and jokes and lambos until someone loses his/her life savings.

comments.author: Frankolala
comments.body: I feel pity for this elderly woman because she was scammed at old age when she is unable to work and earn a good amount of money. Imagine how you will feel when you lose everything when you are within 40 years and above, talk less of when you are 70 years old. This is why as an investor, you need not to trust anyone that you meet online on who they claim to be and don't involve in monetary business with strangers. Naive people are scammers target.

comments.author: SatoPrincess
comments.body: I feel so sorry for the woman, scammers target the elderly because they are more trusting and ignorant of new technology like cryptocurrency so whatever they make easy victims of scams. She lost a her life savings to these criminals in a blink of an eye, it’s not just about the money but also the impact it will have on her relationship with her family because obviously her children must be very angry at her for being so naive. I hope the authorities can take up the case and try to find the scammers behind the crime.

comments.author: Salahmu

comments.body: Is very sad to see how people can be so cruel even after knowing how old she is and still went ahead to wipe every Bitcoin she has without even feeling a remorse on how she will cope after everything, however the only aspect I blame the woman is that she was supposed to know that since it involves money she was supposed to bring it under the notice of her children for proper analysis than making that hasty  decision, however it seems those crypto scammers has something that normally dig out those that has a lot of funds on their account because I don't think is by coincidence they meet the woman. Actually a lot of victims of similar circumstances has lost their lives because of that, so preferably creating awareness to the public will be very nice because since older people has become the target of such crypto scammers so if the media is able to pass such information across it will be helpful, Though what made the woman to be very confident was the Christopher Luxon she saw on the picture because she believes that she was directly dealing with their Prime Minister.

I will always say that the tactics of scammers can not be whole revealed because these people are too smart than we may think and they are always developing new strategies in thrive of luring their victims on targets.There is this video tool I know you to be Webcam, it is a front camera in the PC which when you plays anyone's video in the system and then switches over to video call, the people on the video call with you is automatically assumed who he/she is seeing on the video call is reall but it is a scam.They would mute the video background voices and while the video plays, the scammers takes over the vocal and as the scammers speaks, you would quite believe the people you sees in the video is real so when you realistically believe on the person whom the scammer claims to be such as the Christopher Luxon of the New Zealand Prime Minister, they then uses the medium to instruct you convinceably to lure you and steal your funds.I believe such was a medium used to fraud this old woman.Please let us always watch out and resist to trust online instructors but if need be, always consult for verification and staying updated on what legitimate or illegitimate possibilities it could be.

comments.author: freedomgo
comments.body: Quote from: Lucius on October 21, 2024, 09:39:25 AMLet's imagine for a moment that this woman's bank had been a little less friendly towards investing in cryptocurrencies or had asked the client for additional verification before the money left the account, maybe this woman would have saved her money. These are not sad stories for me, but rather stories about ignorance and greed that are very skillfully used by scammers all over the world.The transaction would still go through since the woman was already convinced she was investing in a good investment. In fact, she allowed the scammer remote access through AnyDesk, where they created a Binance account for her and set her up on Easy Crypto, which turned out to be the scam platform. Even if the bank requested further verification, she would have complied, as she only realized it was a scam when no crypto appeared in her Binance wallet, and the hacker had sent it to their own scam wallet.The exact details weren't fully disclosed, but it's clear that the woman willingly went along with the transaction because she believed in the investment opportunity. And the picture I attached sums it all up.

comments.author: lovesmayfamilis
comments.body: Another interesting point is that Grandma is already very old but still wants to invest. Her lost amount is quite large, so one could think that she did not need money earlier. In the same way, there is a conversation here about grandchildren, and maybe about children; why weren't they there at the time when grandma wanted to become an investor? I just think about my parents getting older; the only thing they want is to be there for the family, completely trusting their children. If grandma was taking care of the inheritance, being inexperienced in transactions, but being at that age, she should have had the experience and wisdom not to risk doing everything on her own.

comments.author: GxSTxV
comments.body: This is very sad and truly a heartbreaking story, some people have to work their entire life to save money then lose it all in one minute. This shows how ruthless scammers can be especially, when targeting vulnerable people like this 72 year old woman who cannot be that experienced in securing her money against very smart scammers. Losing her entire life savings and inheritance of $224,000 is not just hard for her but can really give her health issues, and the fact that they used a deepfake video of a well known figure like Christopher Luxon to trick her in makes it even worse and scary for everyone to trust anything online anymore.Scammers pretending to be trustworthy like Adam Manolas, and take advantage of people who are lacking necessary tech knowledge, manipulating them into opening accounts on crypto platforms like Binance. It's sad that she believed her Bitcoin was safe, I wish if someone from her family saved her befor it was late, also if she talked about her plans so someone warns her.
